content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Many of the mycobacteria are resistant to the drugs typically used for treatment. As a part of the process of developing new drugs, scientists identified two mycobacterial proteins, <math alttext="L 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L10</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="L 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L12</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, that are part of the ribosome and that must bind to each other to allow ribosomal function. The scientists aimed to identify a compound that blocks the interaction between the two proteins, thereby preventing the survival and reproduction of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. As a first step, the scientists performed an in vitro (in a test tube) experiment to test the ability of different compounds to block the binding between the <math alttext="L 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L10</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="L 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L12</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> proteins. The scientists measured the amount of binding in the presence of increasing concentrations of three compounds: <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Results are shown in Figure 1. Figure 1. Average percent of binding between <math alttext="L 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L10</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="L 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L12</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the presence of increasing concentrations of compounds <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, relative to the amount of binding in the absence of any compound (<math alttext="0 micrograms per milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>0</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>μg/mL</mtext></math>, the control). Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus 2 S E sub x bar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. In a second experiment, the scientists performed an in vitro experiment to test the amount of inhibition of translation in the presence of compounds <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. They added the three compounds to test tubes containing molecules needed for translation, including a specific <math alttext="m R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and ribosomes from one of three organisms: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium Escherichia coli, or the eukaryote Oryctolagus cuniculus (rabbit). They measured the concentration of each compound required to reduce translation by <math alttext="50%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>50%</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Table 1). TABLE 1. CONCENTRATION <math alttext="(in micrograms per milliliter)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi control.

control.

(b) Based on the data in Figure 1, describe the specific decrease in <math alttext="L 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L10</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="L 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>L12</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> binding in relation to each specific increase in compound <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> concentration from <math alttext="0.1 microgram per milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.1</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace><mtext>μg/mL</mtext></math> to <math alttext="12.5 micrograms per milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>12.5</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace><mtext>μg/mL</mtext></math>.

(c) Based on the data in Table 1, the scientists predict that compound <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is the best of the three compounds to treat tuberculosis infections. Evaluate the data to support or refute their prediction.

(d) One of the compounds becomes routinely used as a drug to treat tuberculosis. Based on the experiments, explain how a mutation in Mycobacterium tuberculosis would most likely cause resistance to the drug.

skill.text: 4.B: Describe data from a table or graph, including: i. identifying specific data points ii. describing trends and patterns in the data iii. describing relationships between variables
